title: Citi Awards Grants to Honduran Non-Profits
summary: Tegucigalpa, Honduras - Citi recently offered more than 1.2 million lempiras in grants to United Way, FUNADEH and Junior Achievement in support of community educational and entrepreneurship programs. Each of these non-profit organizations operates a range of projects that benefit Honduran communities.
tag-1: Citi Awards Grants to Honduran Non-Profits
tag-3: Tegucigalpa, Honduras – Citi recently offered more than 1.2 million lempiras in grants to United Way, FUNADEH and Junior Achievement in support of community educational and entrepreneurship programs. Each of these non-profit organizations operates a range of projects that benefit Honduran communities.
tag-4: United Way: For the third consecutive year, a Citi grant will help fund "Finanzas para el cambio," a financial education program targeting young people, ages 16 to 21, who are completing their secondary education in the state of Francisco Morazán. In 2013, the program will teach more than 700 young people simple, clear and practical strategies for making more efficient use of their financial resources and the bases of maintaining financial stability.
tag-5: FUNADEH: A scholarship program in computing is expected to benefit more than 600 students in the northern Honduras community of Chamelecón. The goal of the program is to enable students to access the labor market with competitive advantages, such as specialized technical knowledge, work skills training, and internationally accepted certification.
tag-6: JUNIOR ACHIEVEMENT: This year will inaugurate the Mujeres Emprendedoras (Women Entrepreneurs) program, designed to give vulnerable women the capacity to become entrepreneurs by taking risks and making decisions that benefit individual and community wellbeing. The program targets women, ages 18 to 35, who find themselves vulnerable and at risk due to factors such as gender, geographic location, access to education, crime, etc. It offers training and guidance in designing and creating a business and obtaining access to financial support, as well as encouraging socially and individually responsible use of credit. The ultimate goal of the program is for participants to generate greater resources for investing in the future of their households and their children. Currently, around 130 young women from the communities of Marcala and Valle de Amarateca have registered for the nine-month program, which is scheduled to begin in August.
tag-7: "At Citi Honduras we always support non-profit organizations that contribute to the educational inclusion of children and young people in the communities where we live and work," said Bianka Lagunes, Director of Marketing and Public Relations at Citi Honduras.
tag-8: Citi Citi, the leading global bank, has approximately 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 160 countries and jurisdictions. Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.
